name: Kolkata
fun_fact: Fun fact: Kolkata is the birthplace of the kathi roll - invented in the 1930s when a street vendor wrapped kabobs in paratha bread for British office workers who couldn't eat with their hands. This accidental invention became one of India's most beloved street foods.

hero_dishes.name: Puchka
hero_dishes.description: Crispy hollow spheres filled with spicy tamarind water, mashed potatoes, and chickpeas - Kolkata's version is distinctly different from Mumbai's pani puri and Delhi's gol gappa
hero_dishes.origin_story: If there's one street food that defines Kolkata, it's puchka. The city's version uses a tangier tamarind water and softer filling, reflecting Bengali tastes for bold, complex flavors with a balance of sweet, sour, and spicy
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Dacres Lane (James Hicky Sarani), Park Street puchka stalls, Vardaan Market area

hero_dishes.name: Kathi Roll
hero_dishes.description: Spiced chicken or egg kabobs wrapped in flaky paratha bread - Kolkata's original fast food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created at Nizam's Restaurant in the 1930s for British sahibs who needed to eat kabobs without getting their hands dirty. The name 'kathi' comes from the skewers (kathi) used to grill the meat
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nizam's Restaurant (New Market - the original since 1932), Hot Kathi Roll (Park Street)

hero_dishes.name: Luchi and Alur Dom
hero_dishes.description: Deep-fried puffed bread paired with spicy potato curry - the breakfast of champions for Kolkata's working class
hero_dishes.origin_story: This is the most consumed street food in Kolkata, preferred by daily workers for its combination of good taste, filling portions, and speed. It represents the democratic soul of the city's food culture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mohan Bhandhar (visited by Amitabh Bachchan), Decker's Lane in BBD Bagh, countless street stalls in North Kolkata

hero_dishes.name: Jhalmuri
hero_dishes.description: Spicy puffed rice mixed with peanuts, sev, chopped vegetables, and mustard oil - served in a paper cone
hero_dishes.origin_story: This quintessential Bengali snack is the city's answer to fast food - vendors expertly toss ingredients together on street corners, creating a fresh, crunchy, spicy miracle in seconds
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street vendors throughout the city, especially near Victoria Memorial and College Street

signature_drinks.name: Cha (Tea)
signature_drinks.description: Strong, sweet milk tea brewed in clay cups (kulhad) or served in glasses
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Kolkatans are serious about their cha - it's consumed multiple times daily at street stalls where locals stand, sip, and engage in 'adda' (intellectual conversation). The tea at Indian Coffee House on College Street has fueled decades of artistic and political discourse

signature_drinks.name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, refreshing juice pressed from sugarcane stalks, often mixed with ginger and lime
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Found at juice shops opposite New Empire cinema near Vardaan Market - locals drink it immediately after it's pressed for maximum freshness and cooling effect in Kolkata's intense heat

food_culture_notes: North Kolkata has comparatively more street food stalls than South Kolkata, with legendary vendors operating since the 1990s
Surya Sen Street, Sealdah, Bidhan Sarani, and Shyambazar are famous street food destinations
Bengali cuisine emphasizes mustard oil, which gives many dishes their distinctive pungent flavor
Adda (lengthy, informal conversation) is central to Kolkata's food culture - eating is a social, leisurely experience

atmosphere: bustling street vendors with smoke rising
unique_modern: street food culture mixing with tech startups in College Street
traditional kulhad chai served in co-working spaces
heritage tram system still running through food districts
